item.title: New - How do I add an image as a figure into a post
item.description:
ipsum dolor sit amet, consectetur adipiscing elit. Duis eleifend turpis vel ex ullamcorper, id dapibus dui scelerisque. Nulla egestas quis ante id finibus. Quisque nec eleifend magna, ac molestie dolor. Fusce porttitor magna quis dui rhoncus, eget finibus quam varius. Maecenas non velit a mauris vestibulum mollis. Fusce odio elit, finibus in consequat ornare, vehicula eleifend augue. Nulla a tortor id lorem ultricies viverra id a lectus.

This post describes how to insert an image into a post as a figure. Several approaches are shown.

How do I include a figure in my post?

When adding a figure to your post, I recommend that you use the same expression – the {{< figure >}} shortcode by Hugo – to describe both your figure and your link to an image. Figure 1 is an example of one of my figures.

How you invoke the {{< figure >}} shortcode depends on whether your post is a Markdown (.md) file or an R Markdown (.Rmd) file. For Figure 1 above, I used the expression for R Markdown files with the help of the Blogdown command blogdown::shortcode( ),

blogdown::shortcode(
  'figure', 
  src='/negative-binomial-distribution/example-1.png',
  title='<strong>Figure 1.</strong> An example of a set of trials using a random variable with a Negative Binomial Distribution.',
  caption='<strong>This is my caption</strong>')

If you are using a regular Markdown file instead, then use the direct expression for {{< figure >}},

{{< figure
    src="/negative-binomial-distribution/example-1.png"
    title="<strong>Figure 1.</strong> Negative Binomial Distribution."
    caption="This is my caption" >}}

And another example follows:

blogdown::shortcode(
  'figure', 
  src='/images/negative-binomial-distribution/Wackerly-Example-3.14.png',
  title='<strong>Figure 1.</strong> An example of a set of trials using a random variable with a Negative Binomial Distribution.',
  alt='<strong>Figure 1.</strong> An example of a set of trials using a random variable with a Negative Binomial Distribution.',
  class='no-class-listed',
  width='500px')

It appears that caption, attr, and attrlink are not used.

It also appears that the src is reference in $(HOME)/static. In my case above, I qualified the PNG file as a file inside of an images directory,

See src in the call to blogdown::shortcode( ) above. Src is repeated below:

    src='/images/negative-binomial-distribution/Wackerly-Example-3.14.png'

which equates to ...

    $(HOME)/static/images/negative-binomial-distribution/Wackerly-Example-3.14.png

See https://www.rdocumentation.org/packages/blogdown/versions/0.21/topics/shortcode

See https://gohugo.io/content-management/shortcodes/

So where do I put my image?

In my case, I placed my image file – a PNG file – in my website’s static directory further classified under a qualified directory /static/negative-binomial-distribution/,

$(HOME)/railey.io/static/negative-binomial-distribution/

RESEARCH LOCATIONS PLEASE.

What about using a Markdown Link \(\mathbf{![\text{title}](\text{url})}\)?

Another approach to adding a figure to your post is to use a Markdown Link for URLs. See Adam Pritchard’s Markdown Cheatsheet as a great reference for using links in a Markdown file.

For example, if I use a Markdown Link

![<strong>Figure 2.</strong> Negative binomial distribution.](/negative-binomial-distribution/example-1.png)

then I get an included figure as shown below in Figure 2,

Figure 2. Negative binomial distribution.

I like using a Markdown Link because the usage is clean and simple. Another great reference on Markdown Links is provided by Gitlab.

What about including files from a Page Bundle?

{{ with .Resources.ByType "image" }}
    <div class="Gallery">
        {{ range . }}
            <div class='Gallery__item'>
                <img src="{{ .RelPermalink }}" />
            </div>
        {{ end }}
    </div>
{{ end }}

See https://tutorialedge.net/golang/hugo/hugo-adding-images-to-posts/

Here was one thing I found. Kind of gives me an idea.

See https://discourse.gohugo.io/t/how-do-i-reference-an-image-in-a-page-bundle/11637/7

Lot’s of discussion, including a custom shortcode for including a figure.

Now, I am trying to include an image from a page bundle.

See https://discourse.gohugo.io/t/page-bundle-image-references/10750 See https://regisphilibert.com/blog/2018/01/hugo-page-resources-and-how-to-use-them/

blogdown::shortcode("img", match="example-1.png", figure="Figure 1", caption="green")

item.title: New - How to add new page set to Hugo-Academic
item.description:
The question here is, how to add an entirely new page section Z to your Hugo-Academic website. This is to say that you want to add the following components to your site:

  • A new directory to hold a set of pages on topic Z
  • A menu reference that links to your list of pages on topic Z
  • A panel section on your home page specific to your posts on topic Z
  • A index file inside of your new directory of pages on topic Z

The question here is, how to cite references using Hugo-Academic.

On my Google search:

  • hugo-academic, references

https://paperpile.com/s/the-hugo-journal-citation-style/

Looks like this web reference speaks to how to format your citations in the first place, including what tool to use to make that happen.

  • hugo-academic, citations

https://discourse.gohugo.io/t/citation-style-varied-by-publication-types-in-academic/19701

This web reference refers to problems with citation formats. It doesn’t speak to the ‘how’, but it does speak to someone’s attempt at using the how.

https://github.com/wowchemy/wowchemy-hugo-modules/issues/508

Here, the web reference asks about whether citations are even possible. BINGO, gcushion responded.

https://wowchemy.com/docs/writing-markdown-latex/

Indeed, there is a CITE shortcode.

Let’s give it a go. Here, CITE refers to setting in place a link to my own page on my own website. This is NOT the bibliographic type reference that I am referring to when I ask how to reference a citation, e.g, reference a journal article.

{{< cite page=“/publication/preprint” view=“4” >}}

From Bookdown/Blogdown. Let’s see if THIS works. I am going to postpone this for now. I will see how Bookdown/Blogdown handle this topic directly using a biblatex type technology.

item.title: New - How to move a post from one section to another in Hugo-Academic
item.description:
We’ve all been there: you create a wonderful post of topic X only later to realize that you posted this post on topic X under section for topic Y. Argh!

Well, fear not. Correcting this mishap is not that hard. I will say, however, that the easiest approach (I like easy) is to go under-the-hood within a terminal session and use command-line operations to correct the issue.

In particular, always use cp, not mv. That is, use cp so that you can confirm your details before you make (potentially) damaging corrections.

In fact, I may add alittle of bit git branches to help manage the error here.

These are called Go Templates. So the question is whether I can run Go Templates from within documents for either R Markdown or Markdown syntax.

Do these files NEED to be called index.this or index.that?

My problem is that RStudio references these titles inside its editor by using the same name everywhere. All I see across the top is index.this and index.that.

How do I designate a draft page?

I want to designate a draft page so that I can edit a page without posting the same page for public consumption?

HUGO: Check out, “hugo list XXX”

Separately, check out the expression, hugo list XXX, where XXX can be draft or future (whatever future means).

How do I highlight text in-line?

Clearly, I need to be using highlight.js. I can’t tell whether I should be using highlight.js directly, through Hugo-Academic, or through Hugo. Of course, I couldn’t find any references on this topic (either no one asked or no one knows). Then again, I see examples of in-line text highlighting throughout.

I will start again. Apparently, there is no particular method for changing the color of text in-line. The gross recommendation is to state specific HTML syntax, as in here is some highlighted text. How do I add Equation Numbers in my Latex Equations?

Google: R Markdown, add equation numbers to latex

See https://stackoverflow.com/questions/52939909/how-can-i-auto-number-math-equations-in-rmarkdown

Use begin{align} end{align} without ANY dollar signs. This is totally weird.

Using TAG works, but it is not automatic. I admit that I like the explicit tag statement, however.

\[\begin{equation} Pr[X = x] = { k+r-1 \choose r-1} (1-p)^k p ^ r \end{equation}\]



\[\begin{equation} \tag{2.1} Pr[X = x] = { k+r-1 \choose r-1} (1-p)^k p ^ r \end{equation}\]



\[\begin{align} N[A] = & k+r-1 \\\\[0.5em] = & k + (r-1) \\\\ \end{align}\]



\[\begin{aligned} N[A] = & k+r-1 \\\\[0.5em] = & k + (r-1) \\\\ \end{aligned}\]

Also, Bookdown says you can add another expression in your latex equation, as in

\[\begin{equation} f\left(k\right) = \binom{n}{k} p^k\left(1-p\right)^{n-k} \tag{1} \end{equation}\]

By using this form, you can then make a reference back to the equation like this Equation (1).

This is it by Bookdown: See https://bookdown.org/yihui/bookdown/markdown-extensions-by-bookdown.html#equations

How do I box a statement, like a definition, wholesale? A nice solid box?

How do I enclose a full statement as a fancy Theorem, Lemma, Corollary, etc.?

See https://bookdown.org/yihui/bookdown/markdown-extensions-by-bookdown.html#theorems

Theorem 1 (Pythagorean theorem) For a right triangle, if \(c\) denotes the length of the hypotenuse and \(a\) and \(b\) denote the lengths of the other two sides, we have \[a^2 + b^2 = c^2\]
Definition 1 (Pythagorean theorem) For a right triangle, if \(c\) denotes the length of the hypotenuse and \(a\) and \(b\) denote the lengths of the other two sides, we have \[a^2 + b^2 = c^2\]

Perhaps use a new file: layouts/partials/custom_head.html

See https://www.mattmayes.com/posts/2019/hugo-add-custom-css-properly/

See https://wowchemy.com/docs/customization/#customize-style-css See https://silvia.rbind.io/2020-06-16-dark-theme-custom-with-atom/
